reasoning: The critique targets one illustrative “fragility dimension” (scale-insensitivity / population ethics) and argues it would likely be corrected by competent reflection, so it shouldn’t count as an independent persistent fragility factor in the product model. This is moderately central: the position’s Section 2 relies on accumulating many such dimensions to motivate “no easy eutopia,” but removing this one example wouldn’t collapse the overall case, since many other dimensions (digital welfare, welfare theory, suffering, rights/ownership, etc.) are not obviously ‘easy fixes’ under reflection. Strength is moderate-to-low: even if scope sensitivity is comparatively corrigible, the position does not clearly claim that all listed failure modes persist under competent reflection; it explicitly leaves open that convergence/truth-seeking forces might guide society, and the multiplicative model is presented as a toy model / intuition pump rather than hinging on any single factor. Still, the critique usefully pressures the authors to separate ‘bias-only’ vs ‘reflection-resistant’ fragilities and justify independence/persistence assumptions, which would weaken the rhetorical force of the product-of-factors framing if unaddressed. Correctness is fairly high but not perfect: it’s plausible that scope insensitivity is easier to correct than many moral disagreements, but it’s not clearly true that reflection reliably fixes population-ethical choices (repugnant conclusion disputes, variable critical levels, identity/creation intuitions), nor that factual awareness alone resolves it. The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: Scope insensitivity is easily corrected by reflection
